question: How can I impersonate a Jive user when making an API request?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 7 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 25 April, 2016, here is the answer:
To impersonate a Jive user when making an API request, you can use the "Run As" feature. However, the availability of this feature depends on the version of Jive you are using.

In the provided information, it is mentioned that the "Run As" feature will be available with Jive 7. So, if you are using Jive 7 or a later version, you can use this feature to impersonate a user when making API calls.

To use the "Run As" feature, you need to perform the following steps:

1. Deploy your add-on and perform a manual sign-in step in the UI to obtain an authorization code.
2. Add the authorization code to the add-on definition.
3. You will receive an access token that you can use to call the API.
4. Pass the access token and an additional header like "userid 1234" or "email joe@somewhere.com" in your API call.
5. The API call will be executed on behalf of the specified user.

Please note that the "Run As" feature is only available in Jive 7 and later versions. If you are using an earlier version of Jive, this feature may not be available. Additionally, make sure to refer to the official Jive documentation for the specific version you are using to ensure accurate implementation of the "Run As" feature.

In another thread, Ryan Rutan explains how to perform impersonation using the Jive SDK. He mentions that when deploying an add-on, a manual sign-step in the UI provides an authorization code, which can be added to the add-on definition to obtain an access token. With this access token, the API calls can be made on behalf of a specific user by adding an additional header like "userid 1234" or "email joe@somewhere.com". This suggests that the user can use the Jive SDK to perform impersonation in their add-on.

Based on the provided information, it is recommended for the user to switch to OAuth 2.0 for authentication and use the Jive SDK to perform impersonation in their add-on. question: What is the best thing about Jive? Give answer in 10 words maximum.
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 31 January, 2017, here is the answer:
The best thing about Jive is its ability to facilitate collaboration and connection among employees. It allows individuals to work in a more collective and collaborative environment, breaking down the barriers of tribal knowledge and enabling the sharing of niche information. Jive provides a framework for success by utilizing the Internet and web 2.0 technologies, allowing people to work and learn from each other regardless of their location. It is a social collaboration tool that increases productivity, helps provide focus, and allows experts across the company to share their knowledge in a more accessible way. Jive is a better way to do business, fostering innovation, efficiency, and improved communication within the organization.

This collaboration can facilitate and speed innovation as well as help people get more valuable information and solve problems faster in the time-crunch of everyday work. Jive is a social collaboration tool for business that bridges the way people use collaborative tools outside of work into the work environment by socializing project and document management, and knowledge sharing. It is an enterprise collaboration platform that provides documented ROI in many different ways, while leveraging the efficiencies and differentiation that comes along with socialized mediums. Jive allows people to work together worldwide, making it easy to find information or people, and to read or contribute content to those pages. It also provides a real-time activity stream that delivers updates on all people, groups, documents, and pages you subscribe to, cutting out irrelevant information and allowing for quick skimming and interaction. Jive also offers convenience by providing people with access to XYZ in ways that are easy and engaging, such as iPad and iPhone access. With Outlook integration, users can easily see all XYZ activity for someone right within their email system. Jive is a comprehensive platform that replaces multiple tools with seamless functionality, increasing and improving effectiveness and efficiency. Overall, Jive is a website and mobile app where employees go to get informed, connected, and inspired. It combines social networking, Microsoft Word, Google, and email into one website, making it a powerful tool for collaboration and knowledge sharing.

question: What is the purpose of this community?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 25 February, 2021, here is the answer:
The purpose of this community is to serve as an intranet and collaboration space for projects and working parties. It is used to share corporate knowledge, facilitate collaboration, and connect individuals within the organization. The community aims to provide value to its members by offering a platform for communication, information sharing, and problem-solving. It also encourages engagement and participation through various activities such as quests, points, badges, and contests. The community managers strive to create a sense of belonging and foster personal relationships among members to enhance collaboration and knowledge sharing. The community's goal is to increase engagement and adoption by addressing barriers, providing relevant and valuable content, and promoting the benefits of active participation.

Overall, it is crucial to continuously monitor and adapt engagement strategies based on the needs and preferences of the community members.

The community aims to facilitate knowledge sharing, collaboration, and communication among employees. To drive engagement, it is important to understand the needs and motivations of the members and create valuable content and processes. Gamification, quests, scavenger hunts, polls, and personal relationships can all be effective strategies to increase engagement. question: What is refresh token in Jive ?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 19 July, 2021, here is the answer:
The refresh token in Jive is used to request a new access token once the current one expires. When a user authenticates with Jive, they receive an access token and a refresh token. The access token is used to access resources directly, while the refresh token is used to obtain a new access token when needed.

By default, the access token in Jive is valid for 48 hours from issuance. If a request is made with an expired access token, it will result in a 401 response code. The refresh token, on the other hand, has a default lifespan of 10 years. This means that it can be used to request new access tokens for a long period of time.

To make REST API calls with the access token, it needs to be included in the "Authorization: Bearer" header. For example, a curl command to create a new discussion would look like this:

\`\`\`
curl -X POST -i -H 'Authorization: Bearer qwergqefq5bad5fp03rwjwzzyh3da8vyha92wm6f.t' -H 'Content-Type: application/json' 'https://your.jive.commmunity.com/api/core/v3/contents' -d '{ "type": "discussion", "content": { "type": "text/html", "text":"Starting a discussion"}, "subject": "A new OAUTH discussion"}'
\`\`\`

When the access token expires, the refresh token can be used to request a new access token. This can be done by making a POST request to the token endpoint with the refresh token, client ID, and client secret. Here is an example of a curl request to request a new access token:

\`\`\`
curl -u ':' -d 'grant_type=refresh_token&refresh_token=' https://your.jive.community.com/oauth2/token
\`\`\`

Jive also provides the ability to set the expiration settings for both the access and refresh tokens. By default, the access token expires in 48 hours and the refresh token expires in 10 years. These settings can be changed in the advanced settings of the Jive add-on.

Revoking access to a previously granted client or application can be done through the Jive UI or by performing a REST API call. In the Jive UI, access can be revoked by going to the Apps Management section and revoking access to a specific application. This will revoke both the access and refresh tokens, requiring the user to grant access again using the Authorization Code Grant method. Revoking access through the REST API involves retrieving a list of authorizations given by a person and then deleting the specific grant.

In summary, the refresh token in Jive is used to request a new access token when the current one expires. The access token is used to access resources directly, and the refresh token has a long lifespan of 10 years. The expiration settings for both tokens can be adjusted, and access can be revoked through the Jive UI or REST API.

The refresh token in Jive is used to obtain a new access token without having to go through the full "OAuth dance" again. To use the refresh token, you can make a POST request to YOUR-JIVE-URL/oauth2/token with the following parameters:
- refresh_token: _your refresh token_
- grant_type: refresh_token
- client_id: _your client id_
- client_secret: _your client secret_

This will give you a brand new access token. It is important to note that the access token obtained using the refresh token will also have an expiration time, typically set to 48 hours. Once the access token expires, you will need to use the refresh token again to request another access token.

In terms of token expiration settings, you can change the expiration time for both the access token and refresh token. By default, the access token expires in 48 hours and the refresh token has a lifespan of 10 years. question: What is DES ?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 16 June, 2023, here is the answer:
The Data Export Service (DES) is a powerful way to access and export analytics data from a Jive community. It was introduced in Jive 7.0 and Cloud Fall (2013). DES allows users to access user activity data that goes beyond what is available in Cloud Analytics or Community Manager Reports (CMR). DES includes its own API that can be used to access the data programmatically, as well as the DES Explorer, which provides access directly from the community UI.

The DES Explorer is a user-friendly interface that allows users to access analytics information in CSV format through a configurable web interface. Once the CSV is obtained, it can be imported into a BI tool or manipulated within Excel. The DES Explorer was introduced with the Jive Cloud 2019.2.3 release.

It is important to note that the data retrieved from DES may not match up with data from other analytics platforms, such as Cloud Analytics, CMR, Google Analytics, or SiteCatalyst. This is because the methods and time spans for data collection are different. For example, DES uses Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) for its timezone, while CMRs use the timezone of the community. When using data from DES, it is recommended to only compare it against data from DES to ensure accurate comparisons.

To access the DES Explorer, users can log in to the community and go to "Your avatar > Analytics Export". From there, they can change the date range, apply activity filters, and preview and download analytics data.

DES has certain requirements, including a Jive community that uses Cloud Analytics and a user account with the Manage System, Manage Community, or Full Access permissions. It is also important to note the limitations of DES, such as the maximum number of rows returned in a CSV (10,000) and the maximum file size for downloading historical CSVs (180 MB).

For more information and documentation on DES, users can refer to the provided links in the extracted parts of the document.

question: What is the Data Extraction Service and how can I use it?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 16 June, 2023, here is the answer:
The Jive Data Export Service (DES) is a powerful tool that allows users to extract analytics data from their Jive community. It provides access to user activity data that goes beyond what is available in Cloud Analytics or Community Manager Reports. The DES includes its own API, which can be used to access the data programmatically, as well as the DES Explorer, which provides a user-friendly interface for data export.

To use the DES, users can access the DES Explorer directly from their Jive community. The DES Explorer allows users to change the date range, apply activity filters, and preview and download analytics data in CSV format. The exported data can then be imported into a BI tool or manipulated within Excel.

It is important to note that the data retrieved from the DES may not match up with data from other analytics platforms, such as Cloud Analytics or Google Analytics, due to differences in data collection methods and time spans. Therefore, it is recommended to compare data from the DES only with data from the DES to ensure accurate comparisons.

To access the DES Explorer, users need a Jive community (Cloud, Hosted, or On-Premise) that uses Cloud Analytics and a user account with the Manage System, Manage Community, or Full Access permissions. No client ID and secret are required to access the DES Explorer.

The DES Explorer has some limitations, such as a maximum of 10,000 rows returned in a CSV and a maximum file size of 180 MB for downloading historical CSVs. The data exported with the DES Explorer is subject to the Jive Analytics Data Retention Policy.

For more information on how to use the DES Explorer, including how to filter the data and download CSVs, users can refer to the Jive Cloud Analytics Community Manager Guide. The guide provides detailed documentation on the DES Explorer and its various features.

In summary, the Jive Data Export Service (DES) is a powerful tool that allows users to extract analytics data from their Jive community. It provides a user-friendly interface, the DES Explorer, for data export and allows users to change the date range, apply activity filters, and download analytics data in CSV format. The exported data can be used for further analysis or integration with other tools.

question: What is expiry time in Jive ?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 22 March, 2023, here is the answer:
The expiry time in Jive refers to the ability to set expiration dates for content using content metadata. This feature allows authors to receive emails in advance of the expiration date, giving them the opportunity to update the content and prevent it from expiring. The general idea is to have a lightweight app or add-on that can be used in Jive 6.0.1+ and Jive 7. The estimated development time for this customization is 3-4 weeks. The cost of developing the app/add-on and running the service is around $20K, which can be split between the customers who back the project. The more backers there are, the lower the cost per customer. The goal is to convince Jive to include this functionality in a future version if it proves to be useful and widely used.

In terms of session expiration and login, Jive has a system property called "login.rememberme.disabled" that can be set to true to force users to reauthenticate every time their session expires. The session expiration time is controlled by the "auth.lifetime" property, which defaults to 30 minutes. However, when using Single Sign-On (SSO), the process is more complicated. When a user logs in via SSO, they will have a session created in Jive that is valid for the specified auth.lifetime. Once that period expires, Jive will send the user back to the SSO provider to log in again. The SAML settings include a Maximum Authentication Age to prevent users from staying logged in too long. If the SSO server responds with a "valid" statement that is older than the Maximum Authentication Age, the response is rejected on the Jive side, and the user receives a login error. To work around this issue, the user can visit the SSO side, log out manually, and then log back in to refresh the authentication statement.

Regarding password expiration, Jive does not have built-in functionality for expiring passwords for non-federated users. However, it is possible to customize and develop this feature. One option is to set a password expiration period and redirect users to a page to reset their password when it expires. Another option is to use Active Directory with multiple domain access to handle different user setups.

For OAuth2 tokens, Jive provides the ability to revoke tokens and set expiration date/time intervals for both access and refresh tokens in the UI. Tokens can be revoked using the OAuth Client Management feature.

In terms of the Jive for Mobile app, users may experience OAuth Token Expired errors if they don't use the app frequently. In this case, they can manually log in again by entering the correct community URL. It is not currently possible to configure the app to automatically try logging in again if the OAuth Token has expired.

Lastly, if you need to update the copyright date in Jive, you can make arrangements to advance the date to the desired year. This can be done by modifying the copyright message in the Jive pages.

Please note that the information provided is based on the extracted parts of the document, and there may be additional details or updates not included in the given information.

question: Mega Menu
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 4 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 25 April, 2023, here is the answer:
Yes, it is possible to use a mega menu in Jive. The mega menu feature allows for advanced navigation configuration and customization. To access the mega menu, you can go to the "Create" menu and select the "Advanced Navigation Configuration" option. From there, you can edit the mega menu by selecting the "Edit" option on the top left. The mega menu settings can be configured in an editable mode, and you can exit the edit mode by clicking on "Cancel" on the top right.

The mega menu settings include various options such as defining the desired menu behavior (hover or click), selecting an effect for the panel/dropdown (none, fade, slide, push), setting the speed of panel rendering, defining the line height, adding a shadow, specifying a logo image file and target link, setting the cache time for the mega menu structure, and choosing the position of the mega menu (above, below, or merged with the standard Jive header bar). Additionally, there is an option to make the mega menu sticky to fix or scroll it.

The mega menu can be customized further by configuring settings for the general settings, logo, main navigation, top-level menu items, dropdown panel, grid (column), sub-menu items (level 2), and third-level menu items. Each of these settings has its own set of options and configurations, such as defining font styles, background colors, padding, borders, and more.

To export or import the configuration of the mega menu, you can use the Export/Import feature. This feature allows you to save and transfer the configured settings to another environment or instance. You can also save previous configurations as backups using this feature.

The mega menu add-on has undergone several updates and improvements over time. The release notes provide detailed information about the changes and fixes made in each version. Some of the improvements include fixing issues related to menu display, adding new features like edit lock and visibility rules, enhancing the user interface, and improving performance.

Overall, the mega menu add-on in Jive provides a comprehensive and customizable solution for creating and managing advanced navigation menus.

question: Jive Add-ons
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 16 June, 2023, here is the answer:
Jive Add-ons are additional features or functionalities that can be installed and managed by Jive users. These add-ons can be used to enhance the Jive community experience and provide users with more options for collaboration and integration with other tools and services. Add-ons can be installed directly from the Jive user interface through the Add-ons Registry or by uploading a zip file.

Some examples of Jive Add-ons include:

1. Jive Connector for Hangouts: This add-on allows Jive community users to create Hangouts meetings anywhere on the site.
2. Jive Connector for Jabber: This add-on enables Jive community users to create Jabber meetings anywhere on the site.
3. Jive Connector for Skype for Business: This add-on allows Jive community users to create Skype for Business meetings anywhere on the site.
4. Jive Connector for WebEx: This add-on enables Jive community users to create WebEx meetings anywhere on the site.
5. Jive For Office: This add-on allows users to use Microsoft Office applications to create documents and save them to Jive for sharing and collaboration.
6. Jive For Outlook: This add-on allows users to utilize Jive functionality directly from Microsoft Outlook.
7. Jive for SharePoint Online & Office 365: This add-on brings the social and collaborative aspects of Jive to the SharePoint Online environment while leveraging SharePoint's document management and workflow capabilities.
8. Jive for SharePoint On-Prem: This add-on brings the social and collaborative aspects of Jive to the SharePoint on-premise environment while leveraging SharePoint's document management and workflow capabilities.
9. Lucidchart: This add-on provides collaborative diagramming capabilities for creating flowcharts, org charts, wireframes, UML diagrams, mind maps, and more.
10. Rewards and Recognition: This add-on brings gamification elements into Jive communities.
11. RSS: This add-on allows users to enrich their stream with content from RSS feeds.
12. Salesforce/Chatter: This add-on allows users to enrich their stream with content from Salesforce.
13. StreamOnce: This add-on integrates several enterprise applications with Jive to enable content streaming between the applications and Jive.
14. Twitter: This add-on brings in tweets that mention a specific handle or tweets written by members of a list and allows discussing them in Jive groups.
15. Yammer: This add-on brings in activities from a Yammer group and allows commenting on them and syncing back to Yammer.
16. Urgent Notifications: This add-on allows sending urgent notifications and collaborating on them.

It is important to note that some add-ons may require access to external services, and the availability of certain add-ons may vary depending on the Jive deployment (cloud or on-premise). Additionally, the installation and management of add-ons can be done by community managers or users with appropriate permissions.

Overall, Jive Add-ons provide users with a wide range of options to enhance their collaboration and integration experience within the Jive community.

question: Mega Menu Add-on
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 2 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 25 April, 2023, here is the answer:
The Mega Menu Add-On allows users to create and configure a mega menu for their Jive instance. The menu can be customized with various settings and elements to create a visually appealing and user-friendly navigation experience.

To access the Mega Menu, users can go to the "Create" menu and select the "Advanced Navigation Configuration" option. From there, they can select the "Edit" option to make changes to the menu.

The menu settings can be customized in the Theme page by adding custom CSS. Users can add custom CSS to hide certain elements or modify the position of the menu. After making changes, users can save the theme.

To configure the Mega Menu Add-On, users can go to the configuration page via the URL: \`/apps/mega-menu-add-on\`. From there, they can configure various settings such as the menu behavior, effects, speed, line height, logo, cache time, position, and sticky behavior.

The Mega Menu Add-On also supports visibility rules, which allow users to control the visibility of menu items based on user profiles. Users can create visibility rules and specify conditions for when the menu items should be displayed. The visibility rules can be managed and edited in the configuration panel.

Users can also create dropdown menus within the mega menu. They can add sub-menu items, edit their details, and manage the menu items. Dropdown menus can be created in both grid and vertical tab styles.

The Mega Menu Add-On also provides options for exporting and importing the configuration, as well as sample configurations for reference.

In terms of installation, the Mega Menu Add-On can be installed on both cloud and hosted/on-prem Jive instances. The installation process involves creating user groups, setting system properties, uploading the add-on package, and configuring the add-on settings.

Overall, the Mega Menu Add-On provides users with a powerful tool to create and customize a mega menu for their Jive instance, enhancing the navigation experience for users.

question: How to set kubectl to access MAKO?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 05 June, 2020, here is the answer:
To set kubectl to access MAKO, you need to follow these steps:

1. Download the Maven binary from the Maven website. You can find the download link [here](http://maven.apache.org/download.html).
2. Unpack the binary on your system. If you are using a Mac, explode the zip file to /usr/local. If you are using Windows, extract the downloaded Maven zip file to the root of the C: drive, which will create a maven-2.2.1 folder.
3. Set your environment path. If you are using a Mac, add a M2_HOME environment variable to your ~/.bash_profile and point it to your download. For example:
\`\`\`
export M2_HOME=/usr/local/apache-maven-2.2.1
\`\`\`
Also, add the $M2_HOME/bin directory to your path, before /usr/bin.
If you are using Windows, adjust the System Path Variable by appending a semi-colon and the location of the maven\bin directory. For example:
\`\`\`
C:\maven-2.2.1\bin
\`\`\`
4. Test your installation by running the command \`mvn --version\`. You should see the Apache Maven version and Java version information.

Please note that the provided information is based on the extracted parts of a long document and may not cover all possible scenarios. It is always recommended to refer to the official documentation or seek assistance from the relevant support channels for specific instructions related to your environment.

1. First, make sure you have the Jive Apps Command Line Tools installed on your system. If not, you can install it by running the following command in the terminal:
\`\`\`
sudo gem install jiveapps
\`\`\`

2. Once the Jive Apps Command Line Tools are installed, you need to configure Git. Run the following commands in the terminal to set your Git username and email:
\`\`\`
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your_email@example.com"
\`\`\`

3. Next, generate an SSH key pair if you don't already have one. Run the following command in the terminal and press Enter at all prompts:
\`\`\`
ssh-keygen -t rsa -C "your_email@example.com"
\`\`\`

4. Install Git if you don't have it already. You can download the Git installer for your operating system from the official Git website and follow the installation instructions.

5. Once Git is installed, you can set up your SSH keys. Copy the public key generated in step 3 (usually located in the \`~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub\` file) and add it to your MAKO account settings. This will allow you to authenticate with MAKO using your SSH key.

6. Finally, you can configure kubectl to access MAKO. Run the following command in the terminal:
\`\`\`
kubectl config set-cluster mako --server=https://mako.example.com --certificate-authority=path/to/ca.crt
kubectl config set-credentials mako --client-certificate=path/to/client.crt --client-key=path/to/client.key
kubectl config set-context mako --cluster=mako --user=mako
kubectl config use-context mako
\`\`\`
Replace \`https://mako.example.com\` with the URL of your MAKO server, and replace \`path/to/ca.crt\`, \`path/to/client.crt\`, and \`path/to/client.key\` with the paths to your CA certificate, client certificate, and client key files respectively.

After completing these steps, you should be able to use kubectl to access MAKO.

question: What was in the Jive 9.07 release?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 11 March, 2022, here is the answer:
The Jive 9.07 release introduced several new features and improvements. Some of the key highlights of this release include:

1. Engagement Analytics: Jive 9.07 introduced Engagement Analytics, which provides detailed insights into user interactions and community participation. Community managers can analyze user interactions by job type, title, location, department, and other values to gauge the health and vibrancy of the community. The Engagement Index chart allows organizations to track community engagement and user activity over time.

2. Jive Daily: Jive Daily is now a mobile app for Jive-n users. It allows employees to stay connected to their Jive-n company intranet or employee community from anywhere. With Jive Daily, users can read company news, follow personalized activity streams, get notifications, create and edit content, search people and places, vote on polls and ideas, RSVP to events, and more.

3. Content Management: Jive 9.07 introduced bulk content management, which allows users to quickly and easily modify multiple pieces of content within a place. Users can add categories and tags, move or delete content, and set outcomes in bulk. They can also bulk upload multiple files, associate tags with batch uploads, and manage image galleries more efficiently. Additionally, Jive 9.07 introduced the "Copy Document" action, which allows users to clone the title, body, and publishing information of a document into a new piece of content.

4. New Tiles: Jive 9.07 made several improvements to tiles and introduced new tiles. These improvements were based on user feedback and aimed to enhance the overall user experience.

It is important to note that the information provided is based on the extracted parts of the document, and there may be additional features and improvements in the Jive 9.07 release that are not mentioned. For more detailed information, it is recommended to refer to the official release notes and documentation provided by Jive.

Kubernetes allows Jive to access and manage the centralized knowledge, facilitating better support, faster turnaround times, and leveraging knowledge provided by the community and teams. Jive serves as the hub to access the centralized knowledge, enabling collaboration and information sharing among different stakeholders. The use of Kubernetes in this context helps Jive in achieving its goal of providing a platform for collaboration and knowledge management.



Jive is used for various purposes within organizations. It serves as a social collaboration tool that breaks down walls between functional areas, allowing people to connect, share ideas, and collaborate. Jive facilitates innovation, helps people get valuable information, and solves problems faster. It enables global businesses to share good ideas quickly and efficiently. Jive also acts as a comprehensive platform that replaces multiple tools such as pages, blogging tools, search and indexing tools, file sharing tools, and project management tools. It provides seamless functionality, increased effectiveness, and efficiency in communication and collaboration.

Jive is a social collaboration tool for business that breaks down walls between functional areas, allowing people who might never meet to connect, share ideas, and collaborate. This collaboration can facilitate and speed innovation as well as help people get more valuable information and solve problems faster in the time-crunch of everyday work. Jive is an enterprise collaboration platform that bridges the way people use collaborative tools outside of work into the work environment by socializing project and document management, and knowledge sharing. It has strong internal and external use cases designed to provide documented ROI in many different ways, while at the same time leveraging the efficiencies and differentiation that comes along with socialized mediums.

One use case for Jive is creating Jive groups for each class that is taught, whether in-person or virtual. These groups are used for posting links to resources and course materials, video demonstrations, Q&A during the class, and uploading of assignments. When the class ends, participants are off-boarded into groups relevant to their jobs where the conversations continue with all their peers. These groups become knowledge repositories on specific topics and help participants gain the knowledge they need for their job roles. Jive also makes it easier for people to find mentors and ask questions.

Another use case for Jive is as a comprehensive platform that replaces multiple tools such as pages, blogging tools, search and indexing tools, file sharing tools, collaboration tools, and project management tools. Jive provides seamless functionality and increased effectiveness and efficiency. It allows for easy access to information and collaboration, eliminating the need for multiple tools and improving productivity.

Jive can also be used to gamify social collaboration in the workplace. It offers built-in or third-party opportunities to make knowledge sharing and collaboration fun and engaging. This can motivate employees to participate and contribute more actively, leading to increased engagement and productivity.

Jive can be integrated with other systems such as SharePoint to streamline processes, integrate systems, and promote external system activity throughout the enterprise. The rich APIs of Jive and SharePoint allow for creative solution architects and developers to solve challenges and create real-world solutions.

In summary, Jive has various use cases in R&D, including creating groups for classes, knowledge repositories, replacing multiple tools, gamifying social collaboration, and integrating with other systems. These use cases can help convince management to adopt Jive for improved collaboration and productivity.

question: AWS Instance (Minimal Usage) Management
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 07 June, 2020, here is the answer:
**AWS Instance (Minimal Usage) Management**

To manage an AWS instance with minimal usage, follow these steps:

1. Determine the type of information needed for your instance. This includes the Jive Software version, Tenant ID, Instance IP Address, and the Shared Services your community leverages. The Jive version can be found in the top right corner of your Jive admin console, the Tenant ID is located on the System Information screen, and the Instance IP Address can be obtained from your IT department.

2. Provide your system properties if you are using any of the shared services. This information will help ensure the smooth operation of your instance.

3. Contact your Account Manager for assistance with renewing your Jive contract. They will be able to guide you through the process and address any concerns you may have.

4. Stay informed about the upgrade process and schedule. Check the provided resources and FAQs to learn about the benefits of Jive's infrastructure and architecture transition, enhanced disaster recovery, Jive Cloud versions, and new features and enhancements included in the upgrade.

5. Prepare your community for the Cloud upgrade and migration to AWS. Follow the guidelines and recommendations provided to ensure a seamless transition.

6. Monitor the performance and availability of your community in AWS. Jive communities are scaled to have at least two instances in different data centers, with larger communities having more instances. Instances are continuously monitored, and adjustments are made as required to ensure optimal performance and availability.

7. Familiarize yourself with the security-oriented information provided. As a customer using Jive Cloud on AWS, you benefit from a data center and infrastructure built to meet the requirements of security-sensitive organizations.

8. Take advantage of the additional resources and assets provided to learn more about the upgrade process, disaster recovery, AWS infrastructure and security, and Jive Cloud features and enhancements.

9. If you have any additional questions or need further assistance, contact your Account Manager. They are there to help and address any concerns you may have.

Please note that the provided information is based on the extracted parts of the document, and it is recommended to refer to the complete document for a comprehensive understanding of AWS instance management with minimal usage.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 07 June, 2020, here is the answer:
**AWS Instance management best practices**

When managing AWS instances, there are several best practices that can help ensure optimal performance, security, and availability. Here are some key recommendations:

1. **Regularly update and patch your instances**: Keeping your instances up to date with the latest security patches and updates is crucial for maintaining a secure environment. AWS provides tools like AWS Systems Manager and AWS Patch Manager to help automate this process.

2. **Implement proper security measures**: AWS offers a wide range of security features that should be utilized to protect your instances. This includes using strong passwords, enabling multi-factor authentication (MFA), and configuring security groups and network access control lists (ACLs) to control inbound and outbound traffic.

3. **Monitor and optimize performance**: Monitoring the performance of your instances is essential for identifying any bottlenecks or issues. AWS CloudWatch provides monitoring and alerting capabilities, allowing you to track metrics such as CPU utilization, network traffic, and disk I/O. Additionally, you can use AWS Auto Scaling to automatically adjust the capacity of your instances based on demand.

4. **Implement backup and disaster recovery strategies**: It is important to have a backup and disaster recovery plan in place to protect your data in case of any unforeseen events. AWS offers services like Amazon S3 for storing backups and Amazon Glacier for long-term archival storage. You can also use AWS Backup to automate the backup process.

5. **Implement proper access controls**: Controlling access to your instances is crucial for maintaining security. Use AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) to manage user access and permissions. Additionally, consider implementing least privilege principles, where users are only given the minimum level of access required to perform their tasks.

6. **Implement logging and auditing**: Enabling logging and auditing is important for monitoring and troubleshooting your instances. AWS CloudTrail can be used to track API calls and AWS Config can be used to monitor and manage the configuration of your instances.

7. **Regularly review and optimize costs**: AWS offers various pricing models and cost optimization tools that can help you optimize your costs. Regularly review your usage and consider using services like AWS Cost Explorer and AWS Budgets to monitor and control your costs.

It is important to note that these best practices are general recommendations and may vary depending on your specific requirements and use cases. It is always recommended to consult AWS documentation and seek expert advice when implementing instance management best practices.

original:

search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 06 November, 2020, here is the answer:
Jive Rewards is a set of features built into Jive's cloud platform that enables you to use gamification to motivate people to participate in the community. It includes elements such as events, points, levels, leaderboards, missions, strategies, quests, and badges. The default configurations of Jive Rewards allow it to work right out of the box, with people earning points, missions, and badges straight away. However, it is recommended to review the configuration settings before launching to ensure that rewards are being given for activities that meet your community's specific goals.

Gamification in your community can have several benefits. It can help promote and accelerate onboarding for new community members, drive desirable behaviors such as asking and answering questions, indicate reputation and achievements within the site, and drive overall usage and engagement. Jive Rewards provides default configurations that support these benefits, but it is important to review and adjust the settings to align with your community's goals.

To set up Jive Rewards, you can follow these steps:
1. Review the goals for your community and determine the activities that align with those goals.
2. Plan your gamification "brand" by naming your levels and badges and establishing a visual identity.
3. Review and adjust the Rewards elements in the management console. This includes events, missions, strategies, quests, levels, and user badges.
4. Communicate the Rewards program to your community members by posting a document in your Help space explaining what Rewards are and where they can see Rewards elements in the community.
5. Consider enabling the feature that allows users to award each other with badges, and configure the graphics and default message for user badges.
6. Regularly review and adjust the Rewards program based on user feedback and community goals.

It is important to note that when configuring Jive Rewards, you should be cautious not to switch off too many missions or strategies, as event points need to flow through a mission and strategy to be counted towards a level. Additionally, there are other resources available in the Jive Community that provide successful practices, webinars, and examples from Jive customers to help you optimize your Rewards strategy.

If you need more help with implementing a gamification program for your community, you can contact your Account Manager or Customer Success Manager to discuss whether an engagement with the Professional Services team is right for you.

question: What is DES ?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 16 June, 2023, here is the answer:
The Data Export Service (DES) is a powerful way to access and export analytics data from a Jive community. It was introduced in Jive 7.0 and Cloud Fall (2013). DES allows users to access user activity data that goes beyond what is available in Cloud Analytics or Community Manager Reports (CMR). DES includes its own API that can be used to access the data programmatically, as well as the DES Explorer, which provides access directly from the community UI.

The DES Explorer is a user-friendly interface that allows users to access analytics information in CSV format through a configurable web interface. Once the CSV is obtained, it can be imported into a BI tool or manipulated within Excel. The DES Explorer was introduced with the Jive Cloud 2019.2.3 release.

It is important to note that the data retrieved from DES may not match up with data from other analytics platforms, such as Cloud Analytics, CMR, Google Analytics, or SiteCatalyst. This is because the methods and time spans for data collection are different. For example, DES uses Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) for its timezone, while CMRs use the timezone of the community. When using data from DES, it is recommended to only compare it against data from DES to ensure accurate comparisons.

To access the DES Explorer, users can log in to the community and go to "Your avatar > Analytics Export". From there, they can change the date range, apply activity filters, and preview and download analytics data.

The DES has certain requirements, including a Jive community that uses Cloud Analytics and a user account with the Manage System, Manage Community, or Full Access permissions. It is also important to note the limitations of DES, such as the maximum number of rows returned in a CSV (10,000) and the maximum file size for downloading historical CSVs (180 MB).

For more information and documentation on DES, users can refer to the provided links in the extracted parts of the document.

question: Write a farewell message for Scott Brighton
question_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 19 October, 2019, here is the answer:
Dear Scott Brighton,

It is with a heavy heart that I am saying goodbye to the Jive platform today. I've worked with many of you over the last 7 years. The Jive dev community holds a big place in my heart, as it was the community that brought me back to programming for a living after 15 years in sales. Whether that was successful, I don't know, but it sure was fun, and I am honest when I say I learned more in the last few years than in the 15 years before.

It was amazing to see Jive evolve from the "you have to live in Portland to understand it" style plugin extensions to one of the most well-documented open social business environments available today. The only serious competitor when it comes to ease of use and accessibility as a developer platform is Office365, and that is a good competitor to have. Even when we are complaining, we should realize how awesome Jive is, and how lucky we are to have Ryan Rutan and his team to help people out.

I hope I got to help a few people along the way. Jive made me believe in the power of community, and my new venture is a Jive customer, too.

As I have started a new role, I will not be able to chip in on Jive developer discussions anymore. All the best to you guys, and thanks for all the fish, and sadly for contractual reasons there will be no more silly April fools jokes from me, that still show the awesomeness of the Jive platform. ;-)

Yalla, cheers and all the best

Nils

Advanced Ideation is a concept that involves using innovative methods to generate ideas and solve complex problems. It is based on the idea that diverse perspectives and a challenging environment can lead to breakthrough ideas. The extracted parts of the document provide insights into the importance of challenges, a diverse audience, and the historical context of idea campaigns.

The document highlights the significance of challenges in driving knowledge forward. It mentions that even though the problem definition was specific, participants in the campaign generated ideas that were unrelated to the initial question. This demonstrates that challenges can inspire creativity and lead to solutions that go beyond the original scope. The campaign described in the document unleashed a wave of creativity in the nation, showing the galvanizing effect of a bold and audacious campaign.

The document also emphasizes the importance of a diverse audience in achieving astonishing results. It mentions the example of John Harrison, who was able to solve a significant problem despite having no formal training or ties to the establishment. This example highlights the potential for breakthrough thoughts from unexpected sources. The document suggests that organizations should look beyond their own employees and tap into the vast possibilities outside the company.

In summary, advanced ideation involves creating challenges that spur knowledge forward and engaging a diverse audience to generate breakthrough ideas. These principles have been applied in historical campaigns, such as the Longitude Act, which sought to solve the problem of navigating the seas. By understanding the importance of challenges and diversity, organizations can harness the power of advanced ideation to drive innovation and solve complex problems.

question: How to use "X-Jive-Run-As" header?
question_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 17 June, 2021, here is the answer:
To use the "X-Jive-Run-As" header, you need to follow these steps:

1. Make sure you have the necessary permissions: The service account you are using must have Full Access permissions.

2. Configure the "jive.api.run_as.strategies" property: This property needs to be set in the Admin Console > System > Management > System Properties. The value of this property should be a comma-delimited list of identification strategies that can be used to map incoming identities to Jive users. The available strategies are "uri", "email", "userid", and "username". For example, if you want to enable the "username" strategy, set the value to "username".

3. Include the "X-Jive-Run-As" header in your request: When making the API call, add an additional header with the name "X-Jive-Run-As" and the value corresponding to the strategy you want to use. For example, if you are using the "username" strategy, the header value should be the username of the user you want to impersonate.

4. Send the request: Make the API call with the necessary headers and parameters. The API call will be executed on behalf of the user specified in the "X-Jive-Run-As" header.

Please note that the availability and functionality of the "X-Jive-Run-As" header may vary depending on the version of Jive you are using. It is recommended to refer to the official Jive documentation or consult with Jive support for the specific version you are working with.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 17 June, 2021, here is the answer:
To use the X-Jive-Run-As header, you need to follow these steps:

1. Check the Jive version: The X-Jive-Run-As feature is available in Jive 7 and later versions. If you are using an earlier version, you may not have access to this feature.

2. Enable the feature: In Jive 7, the X-Jive-Run-As feature is disabled by default. To enable it, you need to set the system property "jive.api.run_as.strategies" in the Admin Console > System > Management > System Properties. The value of this property should be a comma-delimited list of identification strategies that can be used to map incoming identities to Jive users. The available strategies are "uri", "email", "userid", and "username". For example, if you want to enable all strategies, you can set the value to "uri,email,userid,username".

3. Set the X-Jive-Run-As header: When making API calls, you need to include the X-Jive-Run-As header in your request. The value of this header depends on the strategy you want to use. For example, if you are using the "username" strategy, the header value should be "username myusername", where "myusername" is the username of the user on whose behalf you want to make the API call.

4. Authenticate the request: Depending on your Jive version and authentication method, you may need to include additional headers or tokens in your request. For example, if you are using OAuth2 authentication, you need to include the "Authorization" header with the access token.

5. Make the API call: Once you have set the X-Jive-Run-As header and authenticated the request, you can make the API call as usual. The API call will be executed on behalf of the user specified in the X-Jive-Run-As header.

It's important to note that the X-Jive-Run-As feature requires the user making the API call to have Full Access permissions. If the user does not have sufficient permissions, you may encounter errors such as "You are not allowed to perform this request".

Please refer to the official Jive documentation for more details on using the X-Jive-Run-As header and the available strategies: [Core V3 API - Run-As Feature & Signed Add-Ons](https://thrive.ignitetech.com/docs/DOC-110343)

question: What are the endpoints for Jive Cloud analytics (DES)?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 16 June, 2023, here is the answer:
The endpoints for Jive Cloud analytics (DES) are as follows:

- For US customers: [https://api-aws.jivesoftware.com](https://api-aws.jivesoftware.com)
- For EU customers: [https://api-eu-aws.jivesoftware.com](https://api-eu-aws.jivesoftware.com)

These endpoints are used to access the new AWS DES API. It is important to note that the old DES Explorer site, which was used to access Community Analytics data, is being deprecated and cannot work with the new AWS DES API. Therefore, it is recommended to use the Analytics Export feature in your community to easily access some of the Community Analytics Data.

It is mentioned that there are some issues with the new AWS DES API endpoints currently, but a fix is about to be deployed. Once the fix is tested, more information will be provided in a detailed post. It is also mentioned that the endpoint URLs for API scripts and integrations with DES will need to be updated once they are working.

If you have any further questions or concerns about the AWS DES or the transition from the old DES, it is recommended to reach out to the Jive support team for assistance.

question: Jive Add-ons
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 16 June, 2023, here is the answer:
Jive Add-ons are additional features or functionalities that can be installed and managed by Jive users. These add-ons can be used to enhance the Jive community experience and provide users with more options for collaboration and integration with other tools and services. Add-ons can be installed directly from the Jive user interface through the Add-ons Registry or by uploading a zip file.

Some examples of Jive Add-ons include:

1. Jive Connector for Hangouts: This add-on allows Jive community users to create Hangouts meetings anywhere on the site.
2. Jive Connector for Jabber: This add-on enables Jive community users to create Jabber meetings anywhere on the site.
3. Jive Connector for Skype for Business: This add-on allows Jive community users to create Skype for Business meetings anywhere on the site.
4. Jive Connector for WebEx: This add-on enables Jive community users to create WebEx meetings anywhere on the site.
5. Jive For Office: This add-on allows users to use Microsoft Office applications to create documents and save them to Jive for sharing and collaboration.
6. Jive For Outlook: This add-on allows users to utilize Jive functionality directly from Microsoft Outlook.
7. Jive for SharePoint Online & Office 365: This add-on brings the social and collaborative aspects of Jive to the SharePoint Online environment while leveraging SharePoint's document management and workflow capabilities.
8. Jive for SharePoint On-Prem: This add-on brings the social and collaborative aspects of Jive to the SharePoint on-premise environment while leveraging SharePoint's document management and workflow capabilities.
9. Lucidchart: This add-on provides collaborative diagramming capabilities for creating flowcharts, org charts, wireframes, UML diagrams, mind maps, and more.
10. Rewards and Recognition: This add-on brings gamification elements into Jive communities.
11. RSS: This add-on allows users to enrich their stream with content from RSS feeds.
12. Salesforce/Chatter: This add-on allows users to enrich their stream with content from Salesforce.
13. StreamOnce: This add-on integrates several enterprise applications with Jive to enable content streaming between the applications and Jive.
14. Twitter: This add-on brings in tweets that mention a specific handle or tweets written by members of a list and allows discussing them in Jive groups.
15. Yammer: This add-on brings in activities from a Yammer group and allows commenting on them and syncing back to Yammer.
16. Urgent Notifications: This add-on allows sending urgent notifications and collaborating on them.

It is important to note that some add-ons may require access to external services, and the availability of certain add-ons may vary depending on the Jive deployment (cloud or on-premise). Additionally, the installation and management of add-ons can be done by community managers or users with appropriate permissions.

Overall, Jive Add-ons provide users with a wide range of options to enhance their collaboration and integration experience within the Jive community.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 16 June, 2023, here is the answer:
Jive Add-ons are bundled configurations that can be installed and managed by non-technical Jive users. These add-ons can extend the functionality of Jive communities by adding features such as Hangouts meetings, Jabber meetings, Skype for Business meetings, WebEx meetings, Jive Tile, App and Stream development, integration with Microsoft Office applications, integration with Microsoft Outlook, integration with SharePoint Online and Office 365, integration with SharePoint On-Prem, user profile synchronization, collaborative diagramming, gamification elements, content enrichment from RSS and Salesforce/Chatter, content streaming between enterprise applications and Jive, integration with Twitter and Yammer, and urgent notifications.

Add-ons interact with Jive at a service-level and can be installed and managed directly from the Jive user interface. They can be uploaded as ZIP files containing configuration settings and other data. The meta.json and definition.json files are the most important files in the add-on package. The meta.json file contains information about the add-on, including its type, while the definition.json file contains the specific configuration settings for the add-on type.

Developing add-ons can be done using the Jive-SDK, which provides a development framework for creating and testing add-ons. The Jive-SDK can be installed globally on your system and allows you to develop add-ons using Node.js. The Jive-SDK provides a set of command-line tools for creating, testing, and deploying add-ons.

To install an add-on, you can upload the add-on package through the Add-ons menu in the Jive user interface. The add-on package is a ZIP file containing the necessary configuration files and folders. Once uploaded, the add-on can be deployed and made available to the entire community or restricted to specific users for testing purposes.

It is important to note that some add-ons may require access to external services, and the availability of certain add-ons may depend on the Jive deployment model (cloud or on-premise). Additionally, the use of add-ons may have limitations in air-gapped or secure environments where connectivity to external services is restricted.

In summary, Jive Add-ons are a way to extend the functionality of Jive communities by adding specific features and integrations. They can be installed and managed directly from the Jive user interface and can be developed using the Jive-SDK. Add-ons are uploaded as ZIP files containing configuration settings and other data, and their availability and functionality may vary depending on the deployment model and access to external services.

question: Mega Menu Add-on
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 2 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 25 April, 2023, here is the answer:
The Mega Menu Add-on allows users to create and configure a mega menu for their Jive instance. The menu can be customized with various settings and elements to create a visually appealing and user-friendly navigation experience.

To access the Mega Menu, users can go to the "Create" menu and select the "Advanced Navigation Configuration" option. From there, they can select the "Edit" option to make changes to the menu.

The menu settings can be customized in the Theme page by adding custom CSS. Users can hide certain elements using CSS selectors and modify the position of the menu using CSS properties like "position" and "display".

Once the theme is saved, users can go to the configuration page via the URL provided to configure the Mega Menu Add-On. The configuration page allows users to customize various aspects of the menu, such as the behavior, effects, speed, and styling of the menu.

Users can also configure visibility rules for the menu items. Visibility rules allow users to control which menu items are displayed based on certain conditions, such as user profile field values. Users can create and manage visibility rules to customize the menu based on different user attributes.

The Mega Menu Add-on also provides options for exporting and importing the configuration settings. Users can export the current settings to use them in another environment or instance. This feature can also be used as a backup for previous configurations.

The installation process for the Mega Menu Add-on involves creating user groups for admins and editors, setting system properties, and uploading the add-on package. The add-on can be installed on both cloud and hosted/on-prem Jive instances. Detailed installation instructions are provided in the document.

In terms of updates and fixes, the release notes mention various improvements and bug fixes for the Advanced Navigation Add-on (former Mega Menu Add-On). The latest version is 1.2.19, and it addresses issues related to menu behavior, translations, and user interface display.

In the comments section, there are discussions about issues with the menu position in mobile view, logo visibility for external users, and font size customization for descriptions. The support team suggests raising support tickets for specific issues and mentions that future releases may address these concerns.

Overall, the Mega Menu Add-on provides a comprehensive solution for creating and configuring a mega menu in Jive. Users have control over various settings and can customize the menu based on their specific requirements.

The configuration of the Mega Menu involves several settings and elements. The "General Settings" include options such as the behavior of the dropdown panel, the speed of panel rendering, and the logo and URL settings. Users can also configure the position and stickiness of the Mega Menu.

question: How to set kubectl to access MAKO?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 05 June, 2020, here is the answer:
To set kubectl to access MAKO, you need to follow these steps:

1. Download the Maven binary from the Maven website. You can find the download link [here](http://maven.apache.org/download.html).
2. Unpack the binary on your system. If you are using a Mac, explode the zip file to /usr/local. If you are using Windows, extract the downloaded Maven zip file to the root of the C: drive, which will create a maven-2.2.1 folder.
3. Set your environment path. If you are using a Mac, add a M2_HOME environment variable to your ~/.bash_profile and point it to your download. For example:
\`\`\`
export M2_HOME=/usr/local/apache-maven-2.2.1
\`\`\`
Also, add the $M2_HOME/bin directory to your path, before /usr/bin.
If you are using Windows, adjust the System Path Variable by appending a semi-colon and the location of the maven\bin directory. For example:
\`\`\`
C:\maven-2.2.1\bin
\`\`\`
4. Test your installation by running the command \`mvn --version\`. You should see the Apache Maven version and Java version information.

Please note that the provided information is based on the extracted parts of a long document and may not cover all possible scenarios. It is always recommended to refer to the official documentation or seek assistance from the relevant support channels for specific instructions related to your environment.

search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 05 June, 2020, here is the answer:
To set up kubectl to access MAKO, you need to follow these steps:

1. Download the kubectl binary from the official Kubernetes website. You can find the download link [here](http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/prereqs/).

2. Once you have downloaded the binary, you need to make it executable. You can do this by running the following command in your terminal:

\`\`\`
chmod +x kubectl
\`\`\`

3. Next, you need to move the kubectl binary to a directory that is in your system's PATH. This will allow you to run kubectl from anywhere in your terminal. You can do this by running the following command:

\`\`\`
sudo mv kubectl /usr/local/bin/
\`\`\`

4. Now that kubectl is installed, you need to configure it to access MAKO. To do this, you will need the necessary credentials and configuration files from the MAKO administrator. Once you have these files, you can place them in the appropriate directory on your system.

5. The exact location of the configuration files may vary depending on your operating system and setup. However, a common location is \`~/.kube/config\`. You can place the configuration files in this directory by running the following command:

\`\`\`
mv /path/to/config/files ~/.kube/config
\`\`\`

6. Finally, you can test your kubectl setup by running the following command:

\`\`\`
kubectl get pods
\`\`\`

If everything is set up correctly, you should see a list of pods running in your MAKO cluster.

Please note that these instructions are general and may need to be adapted to your specific setup. It is always recommended to consult the official documentation or seek assistance from the MAKO administrator for detailed instructions on setting up kubectl to access MAKO.

question: what features has Jive released in the last 12 months?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 10 October, 2020, here is the answer:
Jive has released several features in the last 12 months. Some of the key features released in the last 12 months include:

1. Engagement Analytics: Jive 9 introduced Engagement Analytics, which provides detailed insights into user interactions and community participation. Community managers can track user interactions by job type, title, location, department, and other values to gauge the health and vibrancy of the community.

2. Jive Daily: Jive Daily is a mobile app for Jive-n users that allows employees to stay connected to their company intranet or employee community. It provides features such as inbox notifications, news feed and activity streams, search functionality, content viewing and sharing, and the ability to create discussions, questions, status updates, messages, and videos.

3. Content Management: Jive introduced bulk content management, which allows users to quickly and easily modify multiple pieces of content within a place. Users can also copy documents, discussions, or blog posts as templates for others to use.

4. New Tiles: Jive made several improvements to tiles and introduced new tiles in Jive 9. These new tiles provide enhanced functionality and customization options for users.

5. Spotlight Search: Jive introduced a redesigned Spotlight Search feature that allows users to quickly find items using keywords. The search automatically includes wildcards as users type parts of words and provides history and suggestions tabs for easy access to frequently viewed items.

6. Support Center: Jive introduced the Support Center, which provides a streamlined experience for customers or employees to find answers and contribute knowledge. The Support Center helps in case deflection, reducing costs, and increasing customer satisfaction.

7. Jive for Lync/Skype for Business: Jive introduced an add-on that allows users to collaborate in real-time using Lync or Skype for Business without leaving the Jive community.

These are just a few of the features that Jive has released in the last 12 months. For a complete list of features and more detailed information, it is recommended to refer to the official Jive documentation or contact Jive support.
search_phrase: Jive latest features released in the last 12 months
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 10 October, 2020, here is the answer:
Jive has released several new features in the last 12 months. Here are some of the key features:

1. Engagement Analytics: Jive 9 introduces Engagement Analytics, which provides detailed insights into user interactions that drive community participation and performance. Community managers can analyze user interactions by job type, title, location, department, and other values to gauge the health and vibrancy of the community.

2. Jive Daily: Jive Daily is now a mobile app for Jive-n users. It allows employees to stay connected to the Jive-n company intranet or employee community from anywhere. Users can read company news, follow personalized activity streams, create and share content, and more.

3. Content Management: Jive 9 introduces bulk content management, allowing users to quickly modify multiple pieces of content within a place. Users can add categories and tags, move or delete content, and set outcomes in bulk. Additionally, Jive now has a "Copy Document" action that allows users to clone the title, body, and publishing information of a document into a new piece of content.

4. New Tiles: Jive 9 includes several new tiles, including Forms, which allows users to create forms for community users, and Jive Albums, which enables the creation of photo galleries in Jive.

5. News: The Winter 2015 release introduces the News feature, which allows community managers to choose what activity users should automatically follow. It also includes other minor features such as the Subscribers Toggle in Impact Metrics and new Community Manager Reports.

6. Promoted Results: Jive now supports Promoted Results, which allows community managers to create rulesets to ensure that specific keywords always return specific content results, even if the keyword does not occur in the content.

These are just a few of the latest features released by Jive in the last 12 months. For more information, you can refer to the full release notes and documentation provided by Jive.

question: What does expires_in for Jive OAuth 2 mean ?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 22 March, 2023, here is the answer:
The \`expires_in\` parameter for Jive OAuth 2 refers to the duration of time in seconds for which an access token is valid. After this duration, the access token will expire and can no longer be used to authenticate API requests. The expiration time is specified in the response when obtaining an access token. The default expiration time for an access token in Jive is 48 hours (172,800 seconds). Once the access token expires, you will need to use the refresh token to obtain a new access token. The refresh token has a default lifespan of 10 years and can be used to request a new access token once the current one expires. It is important to note that the expiration time for access and refresh tokens can be configured and customized in Jive's settings.
search_phrase: meaning of expires_in in Jive OAuth 2
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 22 March, 2023, here is the answer:
The \`expires_in\` parameter in Jive OAuth 2 refers to the duration of time for which an access token is valid. It specifies the number of seconds until the access token expires. Once the access token expires, it can no longer be used to authenticate API requests.

In Jive, the default expiration duration for an access token is 48 hours from the time of issuance. After this period, any request made with an expired access token will result in a 401 response code. However, it is important to note that the expiration duration of access tokens can be customized by setting the system property \`jive.oauth.acess_token.ttl_hours\` to a different value. This allows administrators to control the lifespan of access tokens based on their specific requirements.

It is worth mentioning that Jive also supports refresh tokens, which can be used to obtain a new access token without having to go through the full OAuth process again. The refresh token has a default lifespan of 10 years and can be used to request a new access token once the current one expires. This allows for seamless authentication without requiring the user to reauthenticate every time the access token expires.

In summary, the \`expires_in\` parameter in Jive OAuth 2 specifies the duration of time for which an access token is valid. The default expiration duration is 48 hours, but it can be customized by setting the appropriate system property. Refresh tokens can be used to obtain new access tokens without reauthentication.

question: What does expires_in for jive oauth api indicate?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 19 July, 2021, here is the answer:
The \`expires_in\` field in the Jive OAuth API indicates the duration of validity for an access token. It specifies the number of seconds until the access token expires. Once the access token expires, it can no longer be used to authenticate API requests. The default expiration time for an access token in Jive is 48 hours. After the expiration time, a new access token needs to be obtained using the refresh token. The refresh token has a default lifespan of 10 years and is used to request a new access token once the current one expires.

To revoke tokens in Jive, you can use the OAuth Client Management feature. This feature allows you to revoke access to specific applications that were previously granted access. question: What does expires_in for Jive OAuth 2 mean ?
original:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 22 March, 2023, here is the answer:
The \`expires_in\` parameter for Jive OAuth 2 refers to the duration of time in seconds for which an access token is valid. After this duration, the access token will expire and can no longer be used to authenticate API requests. The expiration time is specified in the response when obtaining an access token. For example, the response may include an \`expires_in\` value of 172799 seconds, which corresponds to approximately 48 hours.

When an access token expires, it is necessary to use the refresh token to obtain a new access token. The refresh token has a longer lifespan, typically 10 years, and can be used to request a new access token once the current one expires. This process allows for continuous authentication without requiring the user to re-enter their credentials.

It is important to note that the expiration duration of access and refresh tokens can be configured in Jive. The default expiration for access tokens is 48 hours, while refresh tokens have a default lifespan of 10 years. However, these settings can be adjusted based on the specific requirements of the application or system. The expiration settings can be modified through the Jive UI in the advanced settings of the OAuth client management section.

In summary, the \`expires_in\` parameter for Jive OAuth 2 indicates the duration in seconds for which an access token is valid. After this duration, the access token will expire and can no longer be used for authentication. The refresh token can be used to obtain a new access token once the current one expires, allowing for continuous authentication without requiring the user to re-enter their credentials. The expiration duration of access and refresh tokens can be configured in Jive to meet the specific requirements of the application or system.

To obtain a new access token, you can use the refresh token provided by the Jive server. refresh_token = [your refresh token]
grant_type = refresh_token

This will give you a brand new access token that you can use to make REST API calls.
